title: Horror as mum finds a mysterious fungal growing in her Woolworths Discovery Garden plant
text:
A mother has been left horrified after she found a mysterious fungus growing in her Woolworths Discovery Garden plant.

The mother said she found the fungal mushroom growing among several seedlings of oregano.

She posted a picture of the fungus growing from her plant on the Discovery Garden Facebook group on Wednesday and said: 'Okay, my oregano is looking odd.'

The mother said she found the fungal mushroom growing among several seedlings of oregano

People in the comments said the growth may be a fungal spore, which is common and can be beneficial to plants.

HOW TO PREVENT FUNGUS Maintain proper ventilation by leaving your seedling kits near an open window or outside when weather permits.

Ensure that your seedling kits get plenty of sunlight.

Control the amount of moisture you’re giving your seedling pot, soil should be moist but not too wet. Source: Woolworths

'Looks like it has been contaminated with fungal spores and you're growing some mushrooms,' one person said.

Another said: 'They are likely from the air, particularly if you've had them outside or near an open window. Lots of fungi spreading spores this time of year.'

The woman replied and said she does keep her pits by a window, which could explain the fungal growth, but it is always closed.

Another person said the mother did not need to worry: 'It’s the normal breakdown of the potting medium, just keep watering them. If it worries you just pinch it out.'

Australian Tropical Herbarium mycologist Dr Matt Barret said most soil will have fungi growing in it.

'The fungi are invisible threads helping to break down the soil into nutrients plants can use, so it is usually beneficial to the plants, not harmful,' Dr Barret told Yahoo News.

She posted a picture of the fungus growing from her plant on the Discovery Garden Facebook group on Wednesday and said: 'Okay, my oregano is looking odd' (stock photo)

He said fungus growing inside the woman's Discovery Garden plant is unusual.

'There is no danger as long as you do not eat the fungus. If you have little ones you may want to discard it, or just pull out the fruit-bodies when they appear.'

A Woolworths spokesperson told Daily Mail Australia mould can be a natural part of the process when it comes to growing a natural product.

'Mould is found everywhere and in this case is caused by local growing conditions such as moisture and airflow,' the Woolworths spokesperson said.

A Woolworths spokesperson told Daily Mail Australia mould can be a natural part of the process when it comes to growing a natural product (stock photo)

'If you see mould appearing, we suggest gently wiping it off with a tissue or cloth. If in doubt, you may wish to dispose of the plant as a precaution.

'Although the mould doesn’t damage the plant, it is unsightly and usually indicates that the pots are being over-watered and have poor drainage or circulation.'

They said in order to reduce the chances of mould growing, customers should make sure seedlings have proper ventilation, access to sunlight, and to control the amount of moisture the seedlings are receiving.
